questions.question: To qualify for head of household filing status, a taxpayer must:

options.A: Be married and file a joint return
options.B: Be unmarried and pay more than half the cost of maintaining a home for a qualifying person

questions.explanation: Head of household requires: (1) unmarried or considered unmarried at year-end, (2) paid more than half the cost of maintaining a home, (3) home was main home of qualifying person for more than half the year (parent exception).
questions.tip: HOH: Unmarried + pay >50% home costs + qualifying person lives there >50% of year (parents can live elsewhere).

questions.question: A solvent taxpayer has $20,000 of credit card debt cancelled. This cancellation is:

options.B: Included in gross income unless an exclusion applies
options.C: Taxable only if the taxpayer is over the filing threshold

questions.explanation: Cancellation of debt is generally gross income under Section 61(a)(12). Exclusions apply for: bankruptcy, insolvency (limited to insolvency amount), qualified farm/real property debt, qualified principal residence debt (expired), and student loans (if qualified forgiveness).
questions.tip: COD income: Generally taxable. Exclusions: Bankruptcy, insolvency, certain farm/real property debt.

questions.question: A self-employed individual may deduct what portion of self-employment tax as an adjustment to gross income?
questions.explanation: Self-employed individuals pay both employee and employer portions of FICA (15.3% total). They deduct 50% (the employer-equivalent portion) as an above-the-line adjustment to income.
questions.tip: SE tax deduction = 50% of SE tax paid. Mirrors the employer's deduction for employee FICA.

questions.question: A sole proprietor has Schedule C net profit of $100,000. Net earnings from self-employment for SE tax purposes is:
questions.explanation: Net earnings from SE = Net profit × 92.35% (1 - 7.65%). This adjustment mirrors the fact that employees don't pay FICA on the employer's share. $100,000 × 0.9235 = $92,350.
questions.tip: SE income base = Net profit × 92.35%. Then multiply by 15.3% for SE tax (up to wage base for SS portion).

questions.question: A taxpayer has AGI of $80,000 and medical expenses of $8,000. The deductible medical expenses are:
questions.explanation: Medical expenses are deductible to the extent they exceed 7.5% of AGI. Floor = $80,000 × 7.5% = $6,000. Deductible = $8,000 - $6,000 = $2,000.
questions.tip: Medical deduction = Expenses - (7.5% × AGI). Only excess over floor is deductible.

questions.question: The state and local tax (SALT) deduction under TCJA is limited to:
questions.explanation: TCJA caps the SALT deduction at $10,000 ($5,000 for married filing separately). This includes property taxes plus state/local income or sales taxes combined.
questions.tip: SALT cap = $10,000 ($5,000 MFS). Includes property + income/sales taxes combined.

questions.question: The Child Tax Credit is available for a qualifying child who is under age:

options.B: 17 at year-end

questions.explanation: The Child Tax Credit requires the child to be under age 17 at year-end (not yet reached 17th birthday). Other requirements include: relationship, residency, support, dependent status, citizenship, and taxpayer ID.
questions.tip: CTC: Under 17. Dependent exemption: Under 19 (or 24 if student). Different age thresholds!

questions.question: The Earned Income Credit phases out as income increases. It is:

options.B: A refundable credit
options.D: Limited to taxpayers with three or more children

questions.explanation: The EIC is a refundable credit designed to benefit low-to-moderate income workers. It increases with earned income up to a point, then phases out. Taxpayers can receive a refund even if they owe no tax.
questions.tip: EIC: Refundable, increases with income (to a point), phases out at higher income. Benefits working poor.

questions.question: A taxpayer receives stock as a gift when FMV ($8,000) is less than donor's basis ($12,000). The taxpayer later sells for $10,000. The gain or loss is:

options.B: $2,000 gain

questions.explanation: When FMV at gift < donor's basis: For gain, use donor's basis ($12,000). For loss, use FMV at gift ($8,000). Sale at $10,000 is between these amounts, so no gain or loss is recognized.
questions.tip: Gift basis 'double basis' rule: Sale price between FMV and donor's basis = no gain/loss.

questions.question: Section 1250 recapture applies to depreciation taken on:

options.B: Real property (buildings) with depreciation in excess of straight-line

questions.explanation: Section 1250 recaptures as ordinary income the excess of accelerated depreciation over straight-line on real property. Since 1986, most real property uses straight-line, so 1250 recapture is rare. Unrecaptured 1250 gain is taxed at 25%.
questions.tip: 1250 recapture: Excess depreciation on realty = ordinary income. Unrecaptured 1250 (straight-line) = 25% max rate.

questions.question: In a deferred like-kind exchange, a qualified intermediary is used to:

options.B: Hold sale proceeds to avoid constructive receipt

questions.explanation: A qualified intermediary holds funds and facilitates the exchange without the taxpayer taking constructive receipt of cash. Direct receipt of cash triggers recognition. The QI enables the 45-day identification and 180-day exchange periods.
questions.tip: QI prevents constructive receipt of cash. Critical for deferred exchanges to maintain tax-deferred status.

questions.question: A current year net Section 1231 gain is recharacterized as ordinary income to the extent of:

options.B: Net Section 1231 losses in the preceding 5 years not yet recaptured
options.D: Passive losses from the same activity

questions.explanation: The lookback rule prevents cherry-picking. Net 1231 gains are treated as ordinary income to the extent of unrecaptured net 1231 losses from the 5 preceding tax years. This ensures prior ordinary losses don't offset current capital gains.
questions.tip: 1231 lookback: Prior 5-year losses = ordinary treatment of current gain. Prevents loss/gain timing games.

questions.question: Property with a basis of $60,000 is sold for $100,000 with $20,000 down and $80,000 note. The gross profit percentage is:
questions.explanation: Gross profit = Selling price - Basis = $100,000 - $60,000 = $40,000. GP% = Gross profit / Contract price = $40,000 / $100,000 = 40%. Each payment is 40% gain, 60% return of basis.
questions.tip: Installment GP% = Gross profit ÷ Contract price. Apply to each payment to determine taxable gain.

questions.question: For Section 351 nonrecognition treatment, transferors must have control immediately after the exchange. Control means ownership of:

options.B: At least 80% of voting stock and 80% of all other stock
options.C: At least 51% of all classes of stock
options.D: Any amount of stock in exchange for property

questions.explanation: Section 351 control requires 80% of total voting power AND 80% of all other classes of stock, measured immediately after the exchange. Multiple transferors can qualify together as a 'control group.'
questions.tip: 351 control = 80% vote + 80% other stock. Immediately after exchange. Group transferors together.

questions.question: A corporate distribution is treated as a dividend to the extent of:

options.B: Current and accumulated earnings and profits

questions.explanation: Distributions are dividends to the extent of E&P (current year first, then accumulated). Distributions exceeding E&P are return of capital (reduce basis), then capital gain if basis is exhausted.
questions.tip: Distribution ordering: Current E&P → Accumulated E&P → Return of capital → Capital gain.

questions.question: The accumulated earnings tax is designed to discourage corporations from:

options.B: Accumulating earnings beyond reasonable business needs to avoid shareholder tax

questions.explanation: The AET (currently 20%) penalizes corporations that accumulate earnings beyond reasonable business needs to help shareholders avoid dividend tax. It applies in addition to regular corporate tax.
questions.tip: AET: Penalty for excessive accumulation to avoid shareholder dividend tax. Reasonable business needs defense.

questions.question: Which entity is an eligible S corporation shareholder?

options.B: A nonresident alien individual

questions.explanation: S corp shareholders must be: individuals (citizens/residents), estates, certain trusts (QSSTs, ESBTs, grantor trusts), and certain tax-exempt organizations. Partnerships, corporations, and nonresident aliens cannot be shareholders.
questions.tip: S corp shareholders: US individuals, estates, certain trusts. NOT: Partnerships, corps, NRAs.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's basis is increased by:

options.B: Separately stated loss items
options.C: Share of ordinary income and separately stated income items

questions.explanation: Shareholder basis increases by: capital contributions, share of income items (ordinary and separate). Decreases by: distributions, share of losses, nondeductible expenses. Order matters for loss deductibility.
questions.tip: S corp basis: + contributions, + income. − distributions, − losses, − nondeductible expenses.

questions.question: A partner contributes property with FMV of $50,000 and basis of $30,000 to a partnership in exchange for a 25% interest. The partner recognizes:

options.B: $5,000 gain

questions.explanation: Under Section 721, contributions of property to a partnership in exchange for a partnership interest are generally tax-free. The partner takes a carryover basis in the partnership interest equal to the property's basis.
questions.tip: Section 721: Partnership contributions = no gain/loss. Unlike Section 351, no control requirement.

questions.question: For a special allocation of partnership income to be respected for tax purposes, it must have:

options.B: Substantial economic effect

questions.explanation: Special allocations must have substantial economic effect to be respected. This means the allocation must affect the partners' economic interests (not just taxes) and be reflected in capital account maintenance and liquidation.
questions.tip: Substantial economic effect: Economic impact beyond tax benefits. Proper capital account maintenance required.

questions.question: A partner receives a current distribution of cash. Gain is recognized only if:

options.A: The distribution exceeds the partner's share of income
options.B: The cash distributed exceeds the partner's outside basis
options.D: The partner's capital account becomes negative

questions.explanation: Current distributions are generally tax-free return of basis. Gain is recognized only when cash distributed exceeds the partner's outside basis (excess is capital gain). Property distributions never trigger gain to the partner.
questions.tip: Current distribution: Cash > basis = gain. Property distribution = no gain to partner (carryover basis).

questions.question: Distributable net income (DNI) serves to:

options.B: Limit the deduction for distributions and the taxable amount to beneficiaries

questions.explanation: DNI is a ceiling on (1) the distribution deduction taken by the estate/trust, and (2) the amount taxable to beneficiaries. It prevents double taxation and ensures income is taxed once—to either the fiduciary or beneficiaries.
questions.tip: DNI = ceiling on distribution deduction and taxable to beneficiaries. Character flows through.

questions.question: The unlimited marital deduction for estate tax purposes requires the surviving spouse to be:

options.B: A US citizen or property passes to a QDOT
options.C: The sole beneficiary of the estate

questions.explanation: The marital deduction is unlimited for property passing to a US citizen spouse. For non-citizen spouses, property must pass to a Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT) to qualify for the deduction.
questions.tip: Marital deduction: Unlimited for US citizen spouse. Non-citizen spouse requires QDOT.

questions.question: The annual gift tax exclusion applies only to gifts of:

options.B: Future interests

questions.explanation: The annual exclusion applies only to present interests—gifts of immediate enjoyment. Future interests (remainder interests, reversions) don't qualify. Crummey powers can convert future interests to present interests.
questions.tip: Annual exclusion: Present interests only. Future interest = no exclusion. Crummey power = makes it present.

questions.question: The IRS generally has how long to assess additional tax after a return is filed?

options.B: 3 years

questions.explanation: The general statute of limitations for assessment is 3 years from the later of the due date or filing date. Extended to 6 years if >25% of gross income is omitted. No limit for fraud or failure to file.
questions.tip: Assessment SOL: 3 years (general), 6 years (>25% omission), unlimited (fraud/no return).

questions.conceptTested: Failure to file vs failure to pay
questions.question: The failure to file penalty is generally:

options.B: 5% per month, maximum 25%
options.D: Equal to the failure to pay penalty

questions.explanation: Failure to file: 5% per month, max 25%. Failure to pay: 0.5% per month, max 25%. When both apply, FTF is reduced by FTP amount. File on time to avoid the larger penalty!
questions.tip: FTF = 5%/month (25% max). FTP = 0.5%/month (25% max). FTF is 10x worse—file even if you can't pay!

questions.question: Under the Statute of Frauds, which contract must be in writing to be enforceable?

options.A: A contract for services to be completed in 6 months
options.B: A contract for the sale of goods priced at $400
options.C: A contract for the sale of real property
options.D: An oral employment contract terminable at will

questions.explanation: Statute of Frauds requires writing for: real property sales/transfers, contracts that can't be performed within 1 year, sale of goods $500+ (UCC), suretyship, and contracts in consideration of marriage.
questions.tip: Statute of Frauds: MY LEGS (Marriage, Year+, Land, Executor, Goods $500+, Surety).

questions.question: When a party clearly indicates they will not perform before performance is due, the non-breaching party may:

options.A: Do nothing until the performance date passes
options.B: Treat the contract as breached immediately and seek remedies

questions.explanation: Anticipatory breach/repudiation occurs when a party unequivocally indicates they won't perform. The non-breaching party can: treat it as immediate breach and sue, wait until performance due, or attempt to obtain assurances.
questions.tip: Anticipatory breach: Clear indication of non-performance. Other party can sue immediately or wait.

questions.question: An agent owes which fiduciary duty to the principal?

options.B: Duty of loyalty (no self-dealing, no conflicts)

questions.explanation: Agents owe fiduciary duties to principals: loyalty (no conflicts, no self-dealing, no competition), obedience (follow lawful instructions), care (reasonable skill), accounting, and notification.
questions.tip: Agent duties: Loyalty, obedience, care, accounting, notification. Loyalty is paramount.

questions.question: A limited liability company (LLC) provides:

options.A: Limited liability for some members only
options.B: Limited liability for all members regardless of participation in management
options.D: Limited liability only if publicly traded

questions.explanation: LLCs provide limited liability to all members (owners) while allowing them to participate in management—combining the liability protection of corporations with the flexibility of partnerships.
questions.tip: LLC: Limited liability + management flexibility + pass-through taxation (default). Best of both worlds.

questions.question: For a security interest to attach, which of the following must occur?

options.B: Value given, debtor has rights in collateral, and authenticated security agreement
options.C: Possession of collateral by the creditor only

questions.explanation: Attachment requires: (1) value given by secured party, (2) debtor has rights in the collateral, (3) authenticated security agreement describing collateral OR secured party has possession. All three elements required.
questions.tip: Attachment (VRA): Value, Rights in collateral, Agreement (authenticated) or possession. Creates enforceable interest.

questions.question: A secured party perfects a security interest by filing a financing statement to:

options.B: Give public notice and establish priority over later creditors

questions.explanation: Perfection gives public notice and establishes priority against other creditors. Filing a UCC-1 financing statement is the most common method. Perfection doesn't create the interest—attachment does that.
questions.tip: Attachment = creates interest. Perfection = priority over others. File UCC-1 to perfect (usually).

questions.question: Chapter 11 bankruptcy differs from Chapter 7 primarily because Chapter 11:

options.B: Allows the debtor to reorganize and continue operating
options.D: Requires complete repayment of all debts

questions.explanation: Chapter 7 = liquidation (trustee sells assets, distributes to creditors, debtor discharged). Chapter 11 = reorganization (debtor continues operating under court supervision with a plan to repay creditors over time).
questions.tip: Ch. 7 = liquidate and close. Ch. 11 = reorganize and continue. Ch. 13 = individual wage earner reorganization.

questions.question: Under Circular 230, a practitioner must exercise due diligence in:

options.B: Preparing returns, determining correctness of representations, and knowing all facts

questions.explanation: Circular 230 requires due diligence in: preparing returns and documents, determining correctness of oral/written representations to Treasury, and determining correctness of representations to clients about tax matters.
questions.tip: Due diligence: Know the facts, determine correctness, prepare carefully. Relying on client info is OK if reasonable.

questions.question: A tax return position that is not frivolous but lacks substantial authority must have at least:

options.B: A realistic possibility of being sustained (roughly 1 in 3)
options.D: A court ruling in the taxpayer's favor

questions.explanation: For undisclosed positions: Must have substantial authority (~40% chance). For disclosed positions: Must have reasonable basis (~20% chance). 'Realistic possibility' (1 in 3, ~33%) was the old standard but still appears in some rules.
questions.tip: Position standards: Substantial authority (40%), Reasonable basis (20%). Disclosure lowers threshold.
